Data transformation in R can be handled by the dplyr package. With data transformation, we may want to create new variables or summaries to answer questions with our data.

Code 
library(nycflights13)
library(tidyverse)
── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
✔ dplyr     1.1.2     ✔ readr     2.1.4
✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.0
✔ ggplot2   3.4.2     ✔ tibble    3.2.1
✔ lubridate 1.9.2     ✔ tidyr     1.3.0
✔ purrr     1.0.1     
── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors

We use the nycflights13 dataset which contains 336,776 flights that departed NYC in 2013.

Code 
glimpse(flights)
Rows: 336,776
Columns: 19

1 dplyr Basics

With dplyr the first argument is always a data frame and the output is always a new data frame. We usually use the pipe %>% character to pass along the results of a previous function into a subsequent function.

  • x %>% f(y) is equivalent to f(x, y)

It’s important to note that dplyr functions never modify their inputs. So we have to assign our results back to a variable to save them.

Code 
flights %>%
    filter(dest == "IAH") %>%
    group_by(year, month, day) %>%
    summarize(
        arr_delay = mean(arr_delay, na.rm = TRUE)
    )
`summarise()` has grouped output by 'year', 'month'. You can override using the
`.groups` argument.
# A tibble: 365 × 4
# Groups:   year, month [12]
    year month   day arr_delay
   <int> <int> <int>     <dbl>
 1  2013     1     1     17.8 
 2  2013     1     2      7   
 3  2013     1     3     18.3 
 4  2013     1     4     -3.2 
 5  2013     1     5     20.2 
 6  2013     1     6      9.28
 7  2013     1     7     -7.74
 8  2013     1     8      7.79
 9  2013     1     9     18.1 
10  2013     1    10      6.68
# ℹ 355 more rows

We organize verbs into four groups:

  • Rows
  • Columns
  • Groups
  • Tables

1.1 Rows

  • filter, filters down rows in order based on a condition
  • arrange, changes the order of rows without change which are present

1.1.1 filter

Filters based on values of the columns in the data frame.

Code 
flights %>%
    filter(dep_delay > 120)
# A tibble: 9,723 × 19
    year month   day dep_time sched_dep_time dep_delay arr_time sched_arr_time
   <int> <int> <int>    <int>          <int>     <dbl>    <int>          <int>
 1  2013     1     1      848           1835       853     1001           1950
 2  2013     1     1      957            733       144     1056            853
 3  2013     1     1     1114            900       134     1447           1222
 4  2013     1     1     1540           1338       122     2020           1825
 5  2013     1     1     1815           1325       290     2120           1542
 6  2013     1     1     1842           1422       260     1958           1535
 7  2013     1     1     1856           1645       131     2212           2005
 8  2013     1     1     1934           1725       129     2126           1855
 9  2013     1     1     1938           1703       155     2109           1823
10  2013     1     1     1942           1705       157     2124           1830
# ℹ 9,713 more rows
# ℹ 11 more variables: arr_delay <dbl>, carrier <chr>, flight <int>,
#   tailnum <chr>, origin <chr>, dest <chr>, air_time <dbl>, distance <dbl>,
#   hour <dbl>, minute <dbl>, time_hour <dttm>

Available operators include:

  • >
  • >=
  • <
  • <=
  • ==
  • !=
Code 
flights %>%
    filter(dep_delay <= 120)
# A tibble: 318,798 × 19
    year month   day dep_time sched_dep_time dep_delay arr_time sched_arr_time
   <int> <int> <int>    <int>          <int>     <dbl>    <int>          <int>

 2  2013     1     1      533            529         4      850            830

 6  2013     1     1      554            558        -4      740            728
 7  2013     1     1      555            600        -5      913            854
 8  2013     1     1      557            600        -3      709            723
 9  2013     1     1      557            600        -3      838            846
10  2013     1     1      558            600        -2      753            745
# ℹ 318,788 more rows
# ℹ 11 more variables: arr_delay <dbl>, carrier <chr>, flight <int>,
#   tailnum <chr>, origin <chr>, dest <chr>, air_time <dbl>, distance <dbl>,
#   hour <dbl>, minute <dbl>, time_hour <dttm>

And we combine conditions with & to represent logical “and” or | to represent logical “or”.

Code 
flights %>%
    filter(month == 1 & day == 1)
# A tibble: 842 × 19
    year month   day dep_time sched_dep_time dep_delay arr_time sched_arr_time

    filter(month == 1 | month == 6)

A shortcut for | and == is %in%:

Code 
flights %>%
    filter(month %in% c(1, 2))
# A tibble: 51,955 × 19
    year month   day dep_time sched_dep_time dep_delay arr_time sched_arr_time

# ℹ 11 more variables: arr_delay <dbl>, carrier <chr>, flight <int>,

#   hour <dbl>, minute <dbl>, time_hour <dttm>

1.1.2 arrange

Changes the orders of rows based on the value of columns. This is essentially sorting. Each additional column provided is used to break ties in the values of preceding columns.

Code 
flights %>%
    arrange(year, month, day, dep_time)
# A tibble: 336,776 × 19
    year month   day dep_time sched_dep_time dep_delay arr_time sched_arr_time
   <int> <int> <int>    <int>          <int>     <dbl>    <int>          <int>
 1  2013     1     1      517            515         2      830            819
 2  2013     1     1      533            529         4      850            830
 3  2013     1     1      542            540         2      923            850
 4  2013     1     1      544            545        -1     1004           1022
 5  2013     1     1      554            600        -6      812            837
 6  2013     1     1      554            558        -4      740            728
 7  2013     1     1      555            600        -5      913            854
 8  2013     1     1      557            600        -3      709            723
 9  2013     1     1      557            600        -3      838            846
10  2013     1     1      558            600        -2      753            745
# ℹ 336,766 more rows
# ℹ 11 more variables: arr_delay <dbl>, carrier <chr>, flight <int>,
#   tailnum <chr>, origin <chr>, dest <chr>, air_time <dbl>, distance <dbl>,
#   hour <dbl>, minute <dbl>, time_hour <dttm>
Code 
flights %>%
    arrange(desc(month))
# A tibble: 336,776 × 19
    year month   day dep_time sched_dep_time dep_delay arr_time sched_arr_time
   <int> <int> <int>    <int>          <int>     <dbl>    <int>          <int>
 1  2013    12     1       13           2359        14      446            445
 2  2013    12     1       17           2359        18      443            437
 3  2013    12     1      453            500        -7      636            651

 8  2013    12     1      546            545         1      826            835

10  2013    12     1      550            600       -10      825            854

1.1.3 distinct

Finds all unique rows in the data. We can supply column names to find distinct combination of some variables.

Code 
flights %>%
    distinct()
# A tibble: 336,776 × 19
    year month   day dep_time sched_dep_time dep_delay arr_time sched_arr_time
   <int> <int> <int>    <int>          <int>     <dbl>    <int>          <int>
 1  2013     1     1      517            515         2      830            819
 2  2013     1     1      533            529         4      850            830
 3  2013     1     1      542            540         2      923            850
 4  2013     1     1      544            545        -1     1004           1022
 5  2013     1     1      554            600        -6      812            837
 6  2013     1     1      554            558        -4      740            728
 7  2013     1     1      555            600        -5      913            854
 8  2013     1     1      557            600        -3      709            723
 9  2013     1     1      557            600        -3      838            846
10  2013     1     1      558            600        -2      753            745
# ℹ 336,766 more rows
# ℹ 11 more variables: arr_delay <dbl>, carrier <chr>, flight <int>,
#   tailnum <chr>, origin <chr>, dest <chr>, air_time <dbl>, distance <dbl>,
#   hour <dbl>, minute <dbl>, time_hour <dttm>
Code 
flights %>%
    distinct(origin, dest, .keep_all = TRUE)
# A tibble: 224 × 19
    year month   day dep_time sched_dep_time dep_delay arr_time sched_arr_time
   <int> <int> <int>    <int>          <int>     <dbl>    <int>          <int>
 1  2013     1     1      517            515         2      830            819
 2  2013     1     1      533            529         4      850            830
 3  2013     1     1      542            540         2      923            850
 4  2013     1     1      544            545        -1     1004           1022
 5  2013     1     1      554            600        -6      812            837
 6  2013     1     1      554            558        -4      740            728
 7  2013     1     1      555            600        -5      913            854
 8  2013     1     1      557            600        -3      709            723
 9  2013     1     1      557            600        -3      838            846
10  2013     1     1      558            600        -2      753            745
# ℹ 214 more rows
# ℹ 11 more variables: arr_delay <dbl>, carrier <chr>, flight <int>,
#   tailnum <chr>, origin <chr>, dest <chr>, air_time <dbl>, distance <dbl>,
#   hour <dbl>, minute <dbl>, time_hour <dttm>

We can use count to find number of occurrences instead.

Code 
flights %>%
    count(origin, dest, sort = TRUE)
# A tibble: 224 × 3
   origin dest      n
   <chr>  <chr> <int>
 1 JFK    LAX   11262
 2 LGA    ATL   10263
 3 LGA    ORD    8857
 4 JFK    SFO    8204
 5 LGA    CLT    6168
 6 EWR    ORD    6100
 7 JFK    BOS    5898
 8 LGA    MIA    5781
 9 JFK    MCO    5464
10 EWR    BOS    5327
# ℹ 214 more rows

1.1.4 Exercises

  1. In a single pipeline for each condition, find all flights that meet the condition:
    • Had an arrival delay of two or more hours
    • Flew to Houston (IAH or HOU)
    • Were operated by United, American, or Delta
    • Departed in summer (July, August, and September)
    • Arrived more than two hours late, but didn’t leave late
    • Were delayed by at least an hour, but made up over 30 minutes in flight
Code 
flights %>%
    filter(arr_delay >= 2)
# A tibble: 127,929 × 19
    year month   day dep_time sched_dep_time dep_delay arr_time sched_arr_time
   <int> <int> <int>    <int>          <int>     <dbl>    <int>          <int>
 1  2013     1     1      517            515         2      830            819
 2  2013     1     1      533            529         4      850            830
 3  2013     1     1      542            540         2      923            850
 4  2013     1     1      554            558        -4      740            728
 5  2013     1     1      555            600        -5      913            854
 6  2013     1     1      558            600        -2      753            745
 7  2013     1     1      558            600        -2      924            917
 8  2013     1     1      559            600        -1      941            910
 9  2013     1     1      600            600         0      837            825
10  2013     1     1      602            605        -3      821            805
# ℹ 127,919 more rows
# ℹ 11 more variables: arr_delay <dbl>, carrier <chr>, flight <int>,
#   tailnum <chr>, origin <chr>, dest <chr>, air_time <dbl>, distance <dbl>,
#   hour <dbl>, minute <dbl>, time_hour <dttm>
Code 
flights %>%
    filter(dest %in% c("IAH", "HOU"))
# A tibble: 9,313 × 19
    year month   day dep_time sched_dep_time dep_delay arr_time sched_arr_time

    filter(dep_delay >= 60 & dep_delay - arr_delay == 0)

    year month   day dep_time sched_dep_time dep_delay arr_time sched_arr_time

 4  2013     1    16     1256           1025       151     1502           1231

  1. Sort flights to find the flights with longest departure delays. Find the flights that left earliest in the morning.
Code 
flights %>%
    arrange(desc(dep_delay))
# A tibble: 336,776 × 19
    year month   day dep_time sched_dep_time dep_delay arr_time sched_arr_time
   <int> <int> <int>    <int>          <int>     <dbl>    <int>          <int>
 1  2013     1     9      641            900      1301     1242           1530

  1. Does it matter what order you used filter and arrange if you’re using both? Why/why not? Think about the results and how much work the functions would have to do.

You should filter first to reduce the number of traversals a sort would have to do.

1.2 Columns

  • mutate, creates new columns derived from existing columns
  • select, changes which columns are present
  • rename, changes names of columns
  • `relocate, changes positions of columns

1.2.1 mutate
